abstract.text: We will begin building the SyncUps app from scratch by implementing the feature that powers the
list of sync-ups. It starts out as a simple feature, but it will become increasingly complex as
the app evolves.
Let’s implement two major pieces of functionality in the detail screen: editing the sync-up and
deleting the sync-up. This will force us to face a number of common problems in app development
all at once, including view reuse, navigation, alerts, and parent-child communication patterns.
Let’s get the basics of a new feature into place that we can navigate to, and then we will
slowly layer on its complex logic and behavior, such as the timer and speech recognizer.

abstract.text: The first major piece of logic and behavior we will introduce to the record meeting feature is
the timer. This is a long-living effect that runs in parallel with the rest of the feature, and
we need to implement nuanced logic to figure out when to proceed to the next speaker.
Now that we have a navigation stack in place we can start navigating to other features in the
application. The simplest is the meeting screen, which allows you to see the details of a
previous recorded meeting.

reducer. Let’s get some test coverage on the feature, and doing so will force us to come
face-to-face with dependencies for the first time in this tutorial.
We have just one feature left to implement, and it’s one of the most complicated ones. We need
to use Apple’s
API to ask the user for permission to transcribe their
audio, and then start a speech recognition task to live transcribe the meeting while it is
in progress.

so that we can navigate to

exist in isolation, but rather are meant to be integrated in a deep way. One should be able to
navigate to the sync-up form from the list view, enter the details of a new sync-up, and then
add that sync-up to the root list.

The SyncUps application is a recreation of one of Apple’s more interesting demo applications,
Scrumdinger. We recreate it from scratch using the Composable Architecture, with a focus on
domain modeling, controlling dependencies, and testability.
